urn:contentItem:5WRR-1351-DXVP-V34N-00000-00Countries tackling how, when to regulate big tech2019-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:50ZLexisNexisEDITORIALSCountries tackling how, when to regulate big techStaff Reports

The Toronto Star

"In a lot of ways," Mark Zuckerberg has famously said, "Facebook is more like a government than a traditional company."

Much the same could be said of the other tech giants that set the rules for so much of our lives — especially Google, Amazon and Apple. Real governments struggle to tame the beast in areas ranging from privacy and democracy to taxation and corporate clout. Facebook even has plans to launch its own cryptocurrency, called Libra.

Finally, though, there are signs governments are stirring themselves to meet the challenge — and not a moment too soon.

In the United States, the Federal Trade Commission slapped Facebook with a record fine of $5 billion for misleading its users about the privacy of their personal information. In addition, the FTC ordered the company to set up a new board-level committee on privacy and make its data practices more transparent.

That's a lot of money. But for Facebook, even a fine of that size is just the cost of doing business. It earned more than that in the last quarter alone and its stocked jumped 56 per cent last year while it weathered a storm of criticism.

The bigger potential challenge to Facebook and the rest comes from another direction. After years of leaving the big tech firms to pretty much regulate themselves, the U.S. government has launched investigations into how they have amassed so much market power and whether they've violated antitrust laws.

This is a big change. So far the tech companies have faced their biggest push-back in Europe while Washington tended to defend them as champions of innovation. But now the U.S. Justice Department and federal regulators are lining up Facebook et al in their sights.

And it isn't just about privacy, "fake news" and similar well-publicized concerns about social media and the health of democracy. Those are important, but the real stakes for the dominant tech companies lie in a challenge to the enormous market power they have accumulated in just a few years.

An antitrust review could put into question that power, the near-monopoly grip on key markets that lets them dominate billions of dollars in advertising revenue, squeeze out potential competitors, dictate terms of business, and avoid paying tax in many of the places they operate. Even breaking up some of the biggest companies would be a real possibility — especially if a Democrat wins the White House next year.

With all that, you might expect a lively debate among Canada's political parties on how to meet the tech challenge. For the most part, though, you'd be disappointed.

The Trudeau government brought in new rules governing election advertising online and foreign meddling in campaigns. But it had no effective response when Google simply said it won't carry any election ads rather than meet the Canadian requirements.

And Canada's privacy commissioner was left to sputter impotently when he rebuked the company for violating the privacy of 620,000 Canadian users and it brushed him off. It turns out he has no power to tell Facebook to do anything. Even if he takes the company to court and wins, the maximum fine would be a risible $100,000.

The trend across the developed world clearly favours reining in Big Tech, and Canada should be more than a bystander as these parallel governments are brought under control.

The coming election campaign will be an ideal time for the federal parties to spell out how they would meet that challenge.

urn:contentItem:5RY8-RDM1-JC14-941K-00000-00Country Unto itself; Time for fed regulation of tech companies like Facebook2018-03-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:50ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A43Guest ColumnistCountry Unto itself; Time for fed regulation of tech companies like FacebookEmily LaidlawWinnipeg Sun

Christopher Wylie's revelations about Cambridge Analytica's data harvesting techniques of Facebook profiles are just the beginning in a big tech shake-up.

As the debate wears on, we risk marrying two separate, but equally important, conversations: the responsibilities of companies like Facebook in a democracy and the sufficiency of our laws to handle this type of privacy breach.

By focusing solely on the privacy scandal we will lose sight of the forest for the trees and find ourselves in this mess again soon.

Facebook is like its own country with a GDP based entirely on exporting its citizens'personal information.

It has 1.9 billion active users who share 1.3 million posts per minute.

Whenever there is a dispute, it is settled on Facebook's terms. The way that Facebook structures its site influences the news we are exposed to, and this shapes our political and social lives.

Even a decision by Facebook to do nothing - to not intervene to delete certain content or shift content up or down in the newsfeeds - is a decision about the information its users see.

We used to talk about Facebook as a gatekeeper to online participation - like a bouncer who decides whether to admit a patron.

Facebook has far surpassed that.

It facilitates, channels, shapes and censors the information we consume.

This gives Facebook a whole lot of power and regulators need to examine what kind of responsibility this should invite It is because of Facebook's power that the privacy invasions of Cambridge Analytica (and indirectly Facebook) are so egregious.

Facebook is like a town square, but one where only opinions that we want to hear are heard.

This impoverishes us. News and opinion is balkanized, self-serving and fake.

We get our dopamine hit of likes, reassure ourselves that everyone thinks exactly like us, and scroll on.

And there is the rub. Facebook has the capacity to impact democracy in a way traditionally reserved for public institutions, but without any similar public accountability.

The idea of a company with public functions is not new, with debates in such areas as transportation, the media and telecommunications.

Transportation provides an important public service, shuttling goods and people.

The media are critical institutions in the public sphere.

Internet Service Providers connect users to the Internet, which is increasingly important to thrive in the modern world.

If we understand the public function of the Facebooks of the world, we understand that they have power and can think differently about how to regulate them.

What is concerning with the Facebook scandal is its influence on the rights of free expression and privacy, which is normally the preserve of government.

This creates an accountability gap.

Global Science Research breached Facebook's Terms and Conditions by selling the data collected for research to Cambridge Analytica, which in turn used it to micro-target U.S. voters.

We now know that Facebook did not audit or otherwise provide oversight to ensure contractual compliance.

The question is whether Facebook should have provided this oversight, or arranged for independent audits, both legally and ethically.

At a basic level, Facebook failed to protect its users privacy.

More than that, we were dependent on Facebook to be our privacy champions, because we did not know what we needed to protect ourselves from.

The question for the federal government is how to protect users from Facebook.

Yes, this invites scrutiny of our privacy laws, but it also invites a much broader question about how we regulate Internet companies with such power.

The federal government has two tasks ahead of it.

It needs to prioritize reform of federal privacy laws.

The Facebook scandal is a good stress test of privacy laws, and is safe to say all the system failed along the way.

The federal government should also examine how technology companies like Facebook are and should be regulated in Canada, given their power.

There is an attitude around technology companies and the Silicon Valley that any regulation will break their stewardship of a free and open Internet.

It won't. However, blunt, illconsidered regulation of technology companies will isolate Canada and fail to deliver the protections we seek.

We must tread thoughtfully but swiftly, and this requires more than an overhaul of our privacy laws.

Laidlaw is an associate professor in the faculty of law at the University of Calgary and author of Regulating Speech in Cyberspace: Gatekeepers, Human Rights and Corporate Responsibility @emilylaidlaw !@COPYRIGHT=© 2018 Sun Media Corporation. All rights reserved.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RY8-RDK1-JC14-73S4-00000-00Country Unto Itself; Time for fed regulation of tech companies like Facebook2018-03-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:50ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A14Guest ColumnistCountry Unto Itself; Time for fed regulation of tech companies like FacebookEmily LaidlawOttawa Sun

Christopher Wylie's revelations about Cambridge Analytica's data harvesting techniques of Facebook profiles are just the beginning in a big tech shake-up.

As the debate wears on, we risk marrying two separate, but equally important, conversations: the responsibilities of companies like Facebook in a democracy and the sufficiency of our laws to handle this type of privacy breach.

By focusing solely on the privacy scandal we will lose sight of the forest for the trees and find ourselves in this mess again soon.

Facebook is like its own country with a GDP based entirely on exporting its citizens'personal information.

It has 1.9 billion active users who share 1.3 million posts per minute.

Whenever there is a dispute, it is settled on Facebook's terms. The way that Facebook structures its site influences the news we are exposed to, and this shapes our political and social lives.

Even a decision by Facebook to do nothing - to not intervene to delete certain content or shift content up or down in the newsfeeds - is a decision about the information its users see.

We used to talk about Facebook as a gatekeeper to online participation - like a bouncer who decides whether to admit a patron.

Facebook has far surpassed that.

It facilitates, channels, shapes and censors the information we consume.

This gives Facebook a whole lot of power and regulators need to examine what kind of responsibility this should invite It is because of Facebook's power that the privacy invasions of Cambridge Analytica (and indirectly Facebook) are so egregious.

Facebook is like a town square, but one where only opinions that we want to hear are heard.

This impoverishes us. News and opinion is balkanized, self-serving and fake.

We get our dopamine hit of likes, reassure ourselves that everyone thinks exactly like us, and scroll on.

And there is the rub. Facebook has the capacity to impact democracy in a way traditionally reserved for public institutions, but without any similar public accountability.

The idea of a company with public functions is not new, with debates in such areas as transportation, the media and telecommunications.

Transportation provides an important public service, shuttling goods and people.

The media are critical institutions in the public sphere.

Internet Service Providers connect users to the Internet, which is increasingly important to thrive in the modern world.

If we understand the public function of the Facebooks of the world, we understand that they have power and can think differently about how to regulate them.

What is concerning with the Facebook scandal is its influence on the rights of free expression and privacy, which is normally the preserve of government.

This creates an accountability gap.

Global Science Research breached Facebook's Terms and Conditions by selling the data collected for research to Cambridge Analytica, which in turn used it to micro-target U.S. voters.

We now know that Facebook did not audit or otherwise provide oversight to ensure contractual compliance.

The question is whether Facebook should have provided this oversight, or arranged for independent audits, both legally and ethically.

At a basic level, Facebook failed to protect its users privacy.

More than that, we were dependent on Facebook to be our privacy champions, because we did not know what we needed to protect ourselves from.

The question for the federal government is how to protect users from Facebook.

Yes, this invites scrutiny of our privacy laws, but it also invites a much broader question about how we regulate Internet companies with such power.

The federal government has two tasks ahead of it.

It needs to prioritize reform of federal privacy laws.

The Facebook scandal is a good stress test of privacy laws, and is safe to say all the system failed along the way.

The federal government should also examine how technology companies like Facebook are and should be regulated in Canada, given their power.

There is an attitude around technology companies and the Silicon Valley that any regulation will break their stewardship of a free and open Internet.

It won't. However, blunt, illconsidered regulation of technology companies will isolate Canada and fail to deliver the protections we seek.

We must tread thoughtfully but swiftly, and this requires more than an overhaul of our privacy laws.

Laidlaw is an associate professor in the faculty of law at the University of Calgary and author of Regulating Speech in Cyberspace: Gatekeepers, Human Rights and Corporate Responsibility @emilylaidlaw !@COPYRIGHT=© 2018 Sun Media Corporation. All rights reserved.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YMT-K9T1-JBKR-R38T-00000-00Country urged to force Google to pay media for content2020-04-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:50ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL POSTPg. C2Country urged to force Google to pay media for contentJames McleodFinancial PostToronto

TORONTO A Canadian news industry advocacy group says Canada would do well to follow France's example in forcing internet search giant Google Inc. to pay news publishers for their content.

But News Media Canada chief executive John Hinds said Thursday that the federal government will need to take a leadership role if the power dynamic between Google and publishers is to be changed.

Hinds was reacting to a ruling by France's competition regulator, the Autorité de la concurrence, that on Thursday gave Google three months to hammer out deals to pay publishers for displaying their content after finding that the country's press sector was facing "serious and immediate harm," according to Reuters.

"To me, this is an important victory symbolically, because it shows everybody that there is a way to do this. But it also shows that the way to do this is you need government to take a firm hand and to show some leadership on this," Hinds told the Financial Post. "This happened because the EU and the national governments in Europe enacted legislation to make it happen; I think that's one of the lessons we have to take from this."

The Competition Bureau, the regulatory agency that would have direct remit over this issue in Canada, said in an emailed statement that it is aware of the French ruling.

"We closely follow developments and enforcement actions related to the investigations of our international counterparts, particularly those related to the digital economy which is a priority for the Bureau," the agency said. "In doing so, we remain mindful of the different legal regimes in each jurisdiction. Regarding the conduct in question, it would be inappropriate for the Bureau to speculate as to whether it may represent a contravention of the Competition Act. The Bureau must conduct a thorough and complete examination of the facts before deciding whether to challenge any type of alleged conduct."

In response to a request for comment, Google addressed the French ruling but did not say how the decision would affect how they do business with news publishers globally.

"Since the European copyright law came into force in France last year, we have been engaging with publishers to increase our support and investment in news," Richard Gingras, vice-president for Google News, said in a statement. "We will comply with the FCA's order while we review it and continue those negotiations."

The French ruling concluded that because news publishers are so heavily reliant on traffic from Google, they do not have a choice about accepting Google's terms when it comes to displaying news content.

European regulators have been particularly aggressive when it comes to enforcement action against big tech, and Google in particular.

In 2018, Google was fined 4.3 billion euros for bundling its Google Chrome browser with its Android operating system, and last year the company was fined 1.5 billion euros for abusing its market dominance with its AdSense business.

Hinds said that he's hopeful regulators will take action to address Google's dominant position in North America as well.

He said that is essential for news publishers to find meaningful revenues online.

Hinds said the collapse in advertising rates in the face of the COVID-19 global pandemic, at a time when people are reading news sites at higher rates than ever, highlights the problem.

"I think it's a fundamental thing: We need to be paid for our content. We need to be compensated," Hinds said. "You've seen advertising drop 60 or 70 per cent, and who knows when those revenues are going to come back. So now more than ever I think there's a need to transition to the digital world, and if you can't secure a revenue source in a digital world, it doesn't bode well for the future of the medium." urn:contentItem:5YMS-Y0C1-DY2T-F3G3-00000-00Country urged to force Google to pay media for content2020-04-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:36:50ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL POSTPg. A16Country urged to force Google to pay media for contentJAMES MCLEODFinancial PostToronto

TORONTO A Canadian news industry advocacy group says Canada would do well to follow France's example in forcing internet search giant Google Inc. to pay news publishers for their content.

But News Media Canada chief executive John Hinds said Thursday that the federal government will need to take a leadership role if the power dynamic between Google and publishers is to be changed.

Hinds was reacting to a ruling by France's competition regulator, the Autorité de la concurrence, that on Thursday gave Google three months to hammer out deals to pay publishers for displaying their content after finding that the country's press sector was facing "serious and immediate harm," according to Reuters.

"To me, this is an important victory symbolically, because it shows everybody that there is a way to do this. But it also shows that the way to do this is you need government to take a firm hand and to show some leadership on this," Hinds told the Financial Post. "This happened because the EU and the national governments in Europe enacted legislation to make it happen; I think that's one of the lessons we have to take from this."

The Competition Bureau, the regulatory agency that would have direct remit over this issue in Canada, said in an emailed statement that it is aware of the French ruling.

"We closely follow developments and enforcement actions related to the investigations of our international counterparts, particularly those related to the digital economy which is a priority for the Bureau," the agency said. "In doing so, we remain mindful of the different legal regimes in each jurisdiction. Regarding the conduct in question, it would be inappropriate for the Bureau to speculate as to whether it may represent a contravention of the Competition Act. The Bureau must conduct a thorough and complete examination of the facts before deciding whether to challenge any type of alleged conduct."

In response to a request for comment, Google addressed the French ruling but did not say how the decision would affect how they do business with news publishers globally.

"Since the European copyright law came into force in France last year, we have been engaging with publishers to increase our support and investment in news," Richard Gingras, vice-president for Google News, said in a statement. "We will comply with the FCA's order while we review it and continue those negotiations."

The French ruling concluded that because news publishers are so heavily reliant on traffic from Google, they do not have a choice about accepting Google's terms when it comes to displaying news content.

European regulators have been particularly aggressive when it comes to enforcement action against big tech, and Google in particular.

In 2018, Google was fined 4.3 billion euros for bundling its Google Chrome browser with its Android operating system, and last year the company was fined 1.5 billion euros for abusing its market dominance with its AdSense business.

Hinds said that he's hopeful regulators will take action to address Google's dominant position in North America as well.

He said that is essential for news publishers to find meaningful revenues online.

Hinds said the collapse in advertising rates in the face of the COVID-19 global pandemic, at a time when people are reading news sites at higher rates than ever, highlights the problem.

"I think it's a fundamental thing: We need to be paid for our content. We need to be compensated," Hinds said. "You've seen advertising drop 60 or 70 per cent, and who knows when those revenues are going to come back. So now more than ever I think there's a need to transition to the digital world, and if you can't secure a revenue source in a digital world, it doesn't bode well for the future of the medium." THE latest conviction rates for child abuse images Lincolnshire have been revealed - with less than half of those tried last year found guilty.

In 2019, there were 35 prosecutions with 15 convictions - a rate of 43 per cent, falling from the previous year.

The conviction rate for crimes related to making, distributing, or possessing indecent images of children has fallen in Lincolnshire from 65 per cent in 2018 - when it was the highest rate recorded since 2009, when comparable figures began.

The rate in 2019 is the lowest out of all police forces in England and Wales.

Of the 35 prosecutions, those involving white men aged between 30 and 39 were the most common, a total of four www.cases.No women were involved in the cases, while two cases involved young people aged between 18 and 20, and one case involved someone aged 70 or over.

White people were the only suspects prosecuted. However, there were four prosecutions where the ethnicity was unknown.

Of the 35 convictions in Lincolnshire last year, people were jailed on 18 occasions, with sentences ranging from between 12 and 18 months to three years.

Five sentences were suspended while four received a community sentence.

There were 4,782 prosecutions in England and Wales in 2019 relating to child abuse images.

Of those, 2,479 ended with a conviction, or 52 per cent.

That proportion was similar to the previous year when it was 52 per cent. Since 2009, the conviction rate has ranged between 46 per cent and 53 per cent.

Of the 4,782 prosecutions, 42 were against children aged up to and including 17 years old - of which one was against someone aged between 12 and 14 years old.

There were also 243 against people aged 70 or older.

There were 23 proceedings against women.

White people were more likely to be prosecuted - with 3,174 prosecutions - than black people (55) and those from other ethnic backgrounds (1,553).

There were 459 immediate custody sentences, ranging between a month - the shortest - and over 10 years and up to and including 15 years - the longest.

Out of the 2,339 sentences, three ended with absolute discharges and six with a fine, 997 were suspended (43 per cent) and in 673 (29 per cent) cases community orders were given.

Commenting on the figures, Andy Burrows, NSPCC Head of Child Safety Online Policy, said: "Children endure appalling abuse for these kind of images and videos to be created and shared.

"However, law enforcement cannot solve this problem alone - big tech companies must be made to use their expertise and resources to quickly remove them from their platforms and iden- must quickly from platforms.

Burrows, tify who put them there in the first place.

"Our Government can lead the world in tackling the threat if it presses ahead with the Online Harms Bill and creates a regulator that has the power to take criminal action against tech firms who fail to protect young people on their platforms." According to Deborah Denis, CEO of the charity Stop It Now! helpline, parents, grandparents and carers have a vital role to play in learning more about online safety, and teaching children that safety when on a phone, tablet or laptop is just as important as when in the street.

For advice on child safety, or if you need help with your own or someone else's behaviour, call Stop It Now! on 0808 1000 900 or the NSPCC on 0808 800 5000.
